metadata./Keywords: Pulmonary embolism; Hemophiliac; Factor V deficiency; Factor VIII deficiency; Pregnancy
metadata./Title: Pulmonary embolism in a hemophiliac patient with factor V and VIII deficiency: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background: Background This is an interesting and unexpected thromboembolic event in a hemophiliac patient.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation This is a case of a 33-year-old primigravidarum of Indian Asian origin with Factor V and Factor 
VIII deficiency who developed a case of pulmonary embolism during the course of her pregnancy after presenting 
to the emergency department in Leicester, United Kingdom, with hemoptysis, tachycardia, and tachypnea. Patient 
was subsequently diagnosed with pulmonary embolism after a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram 
and was treated with therapeutic daltaparin, a low-molecular-weight heparin.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion In conclusion, a thromboembolic event is not an improbable event in a hemophiliac patient and should 
be considered despite a low Well’s score.
Keywords  Pulmonary embolism, Hemophiliac, Factor V deficiency, Factor VIII deficiency, Pregnancy
Background
Pulmonary embolism (PE) is defined by National Insti tute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) as a condi tion in which one or more emboli, usually arising from a 
thrombus formed in the veins, are lodged in and obstruct 
the pulmonary arterial system, causing severe respiratory 
dysfunction [1].
Combined Factor V and VIII deficiency is inherited in 
an autosomal recessive pattern caused by a genetic muta tion involved in the intracellular transport of factor V 
and VII instead of the DNA gene defect that encodes it. 
It occurs in about 1:1,000,000 in the general population 
and is associated with a mild to moderate bleeding disor der. This can be treated with replacement of Factor V and VIII with fresh frozen plasma (FFP), factor concentrate, 
and desmopressin [2, 3].
Case evaluation
A 33-year-old primigravida of Indian Asian origin at 
32  weeks and 4  days gestation presented to the emer gency department with chest pain, shortness of breath 
(SOB), and hemoptysis.
On examination, the patient was tachypneic and tachy cardic, with oxygen saturation ranging from 95% to 100% 
on room air. Bilateral scattered wheeze on auscultation 
with no crepitations was noted.
Past medical history is significant for a combined Fac tor V and Factor VIII deficiency, which was incidentally 
diagnosed when she presented to the emergency depart ment 3  years ago with similar symptoms and routine 
blood test revealed mild coagulopathy that was later 
diagnosed as a combined Factor V and Factor VIII defi ciency. However, the patient was diagnosed and treated 
for viral respiratory tract infection at that time and dis charged well without follow-up and with no mention of Open Access

*Correspondence:
Yap SuHao
suhao.yap@uhl-tr.nhs.uk
1 Clinical Fellow in Obstetrics Anaesthetic Department, Leicester Royal 
Infirmary, Leicester, UK
2 Consultant anaesthetists, Leicester Royal Infirmary, Leicester, UK
Page 2 of 3 SuHao and Vedantham  Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:481 
PE as a differential diagnosis. Patient was otherwise fit 
and well with no other significant past medical history or 
family history of coagulopathy.
Hematological and radiological investigations
Blood testing revealed mild anemia of a hemoglobin of 
98  g/L, C-reactive protein of 12  mg/L, an international 
normalized ratio (INR) of 1.4, an activated partial throm boplastin time (APTT) of 82.6 seconds, and a body mass 
index (BMI) of 20.3 kg/m3.
PR3-ANCA and MPO-ANCA were negative, a 
D-Dimer was not done, and coronavirus disease 
(COVID) testing was negative.
Chest X-Ray revealed no consolidations/pleural 
effusion.
The ventilation perfusion scan was inconclusive due to 
suboptimal
sections.Results:
results with patchy tracer distribution and no 
definite mismatch.
Computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) 
showed subacute PE in the right lobar pulmonary artery. 
(Fig. 1).
Diagnosis: Subacute PE
The hematologist was consulted and suggested treat ment of PE with a therapeutic dose of the low-molecularweight heparin (LMWH) dalteparin 7000 U once in the 
morning and 5000 U once at night; this dose was based on the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists 
Green-top Guidelines [4]. There were no diagnostic dif ficulties or delay to treatment.
The patient later developed productive sputum and 
wheeze and was also treated for an infective exacerba tion of asthma with amoxicillin, inhalers, and a course 
of prednisolone. Patient was stabilized and subsequently 
transferred to a respiratory medical team where she was 
later diagnosed with likely undiagnosed eosinophilic 
asthma. The patient was discharged well with a follow-up 
appointment with the hematologists to review and devise 
a plan for her anticoagulation treatment before delivery 
of the baby. The advantages and disadvantages of stop ping or bridging anticoagulation during the time of deliv ery should be communicated with the patient, discussing 
the risks of bleeding versus further thromboembolic 
events.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
In view of the history of Factor V and Factor VIII defi ciency, a pulmonary embolism was not on the top of the 
list of differentials. However, the clinical presentation was 
very suggestive of a PE, and pregnancy is a well-known 
risk factor for a venous thromboembolic event.
The pathophysiology of a venous thromboembolic 
event depends on three factors of Virchow’s triad, includ ing hypercoagulability, flow stasis, and endothelial injury 
[5].
When PE predictive tools were used, the same risk fac tors were found: tachycardia and hemoptysis scored 2.5 
points on Well’s score [8] for PE, and 7 points on Geneva 
revised score [9], respectively. Both scoring systems 
translate to a moderate risk for PE at 16.2% and 20–30% 
for the latter.
It is worth noting that the patient’s Factor V and VIII 
showed an increasing trend since her pregnancy com menced. Hence, a thromboembolic event had occurred 
despite the factor V levels being well below the normal 
laboratory reference range, and Factor VIII being at levels 
within the normal range. (Fig. 2).
Upon literary review, there was a notable case where a 
25-year-old male with a moderate degree of hemophilia 
A (Factor VIII deficiency) received concentrated Factor 
VIII replacement therapy for a traumatic splenic injury 
in which he underwent an exploratory laparotomy and 
Fig. 1 Arrow pointing to a filling defect in the right lobar pulmonary 
artery on a CTPA
Fig. 2 Laboratory investigations of Factor V and VIII levels with reference range. FV Lab Ref. 53.8–217.3 IU/dL; FVIII Lab Ref. 64.8–141.9 IU/dL
Page 3 of 3
 SuHao and Vedantham  Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:481 
 
splenectomy after correction of prothrombin time (PT)/
partial thromboplastin time (PTT) to within normal 
range, and INR corrected to 1.6 from 2.2 prior to replace ment therapy. Unfortunately, the patient subsequently 
passed away within a day from a massive pulmonary 
thromboembolism [6].
Another interesting case study was based on a 64-yearold female with autoimmune disease that was compli cated by acquired hemophilia from decreased Factor VIII 
activity, caused by autoantibodies that inhibit the factor. 
She developed a spontaneous hematoma in her thigh and 
was found to have increased PTT of 81.8  seconds and 
low Factor VIII activity, which was < 6%, when planning 
for an evacuation of hematoma. She was then treated 
with Factor VIII inhibitor bypass activity (FEIBA), fresh 
frozen plasma (FFP), and vitamin K prior to evacuation 
of the hematoma. Surgery was uneventful, but postop eratively, the patient developed chest pain, and a bedside 
echocardiogram showed hyperdynamic left ventricular 
ejection with an impaired diastolic dysfunction. No fur ther investigations were done in view of patient’s poor 
comorbidities, and cause of death was deemed most 
likely secondary to a PE [7].
These two case studies are essentially still different 
from the main case study, as they both had interventions 
or treatments to correct the existing coagulation defect, 
whereas our patient had normal coagulation levels.
Conclusion
A thromboembolic event is often not the first thing that 
comes to a physician’s mind for patients with hemophilia. 
However, this case illustrates that it is not improbable and 
that perhaps every hemophiliac patient, especially those 
with mild and moderate manifestation of the condition 
should be counseled for risk of clotting in pregnancy.
From the three cases illustrated in this report, Factor 
VIII appears to be a more significant cause of thrombotic 
events as compared with Factor V, and a PE can occur 
even when the levels are within normal reference range 
in the presence of a major risk factor.
This begs the question of whether patients with mild to 
moderate hemophilia should have their factors levels moni tored and treated with low-molecular-weight heparin if 
the levels are beyond normal. In conclusion, every case is 
unique in its own way and should be dealt with in a multi disciplinary manner with the involved specialist for a com bined shared decision-making to improve patient care. In 
this patient’s case, she was treated for PE, as she was symp tomatic and would be considered at higher risk of venous 
thromboembolic event in future pregnancies. The current 
plan was to continue therapeutic coagulation until planned delivery to ensure that it is stopped in time to facilitate 
regional anesthesia as an anesthetic or analgesic option.
